awd_titl_txt: Exploratory: Life STEM: Promoting STEM Career Awareness, Engagement, and Identity, via a Culturally Relevant and Technology-Infused STEM-Based Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by engaging in hands-on field experience, laboratory/project-based entrepreneurship tasks and mentorship experiences.

The NSF ITEST program supports research on the design, development, implementation, and selective spread of innovative strategies for engaging students in technology-rich experiences.

This Innovative Technology Experience for Students and Teachers project will expose underrepresented minority (URM) 3rd-5th grade students to a range of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) careers, and promote positive STEM identities by piloting a novel STEM Academy infused with technology and culturally relevant STEM career-based modules. This 2-year exploratory project will develop a sustainable program to engage URM students, make them aware of STEM careers, and motivate them to consider educational pathways to STEM careers. This project will create training and mentoring opportunities for students, teachers, and families through a partnership between a minority-serving institution and elementary schools that are federally designated as low-performing focus or priority schools. The project will also advance knowledge related to educational, psychosocial, and family factors that may determine whether URM students persist in the STEM education-to-career pipeline. 

This project will enhance 3rd-5th grade STEM curricula by developing and implementing culturally relevant and responsive modules. The project will explore factors influencing URM students' learning and efficacy in STEM, while developing a platform for teachers to better understand socio-cultural and environmental impacts on URM students' engagement in STEM and interest in STEM careers. The four major goals are as follows: 1) develop an effective partnership that promotes a collaborative and synergistic STEM Learning Ecosystem between teachers, students, parents/families and STEM career partners; 2) utilize best practices to create an intentional, stakeholder-vetted, culturally relevant, and technology-rich STEM Academy geared toward promoting STEM occupational awareness; 3) develop a reflective capstone project that encourages application of ideas, skills, and knowledge gained during the Academy, and 4) develop purposeful mechanisms and utilize innovative technologies to bridge the gap between at-school and at-home learning. The project goals will be evaluated utilizing a mixed methods design including surveys, the Draw-a-Scientist Test (DAST), the capstone project, and feedback from focus groups.  These data sources will elucidate the impact of the technology-infused culturally relevant pedagogical interventions on STEM career knowledge, science/scientist identity, and STEM self-efficacy. Hence, the project will engage both students and stakeholders while focusing specifically on building students' STEM identities via a STEM Academy

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.inst_street_address: 601 S MARTIN LUTHER KING JR DR

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 601 S. Martin Luther King Jr Dri

por.por_cntn:
The Winston-Salem State university STEM for Everyone project was a two-year, $400,000.00 exploratory project funded by a National Science Foundation (NSF) Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) grant. This NSF grant (1850283) was awarded to an interdisciplinary team of scholars in the departments of psychological sciences, chemistry, biology, education, computer science, and exercise physiology in April of 2019, and the PI requested one no-cost extension for 2021-2022. We provided opportunities to embed 3rd – 5th-grade students in intensive, technology-rich experiences that fostered STEM interest and engagement by developing a model program exposing students to a range of STEM careers and promoting positive STEM identities via a pilot STEM academy infused with our technology-rich, culturally relevant STEM career-based modules. In addition, we strove to increase students’ awareness of STEM occupations and support student engagement via culturally relevant learning activities that enhance learners’ identity, motivation, and mindset while also providing students opportunities to learn and practice those interpersonal and intra-personal skills necessary for the STEM workplace to advance our understanding of fostering student interest and capacities to participate in the STEM workforce. Further, we developed a 30-hour STEM for Everyone Teacher Professional Development program to immerse teachers in culturally responsive pedagogies for science learning.

Module Development

Our team developed eight culturally responsive STEM career modules and associated teacher lesson plans to engage students in an exploration of STEM career options and to connect their in-school learning experiences with at-home learning experiences, which also acted as a mechanism to engage parents in their children’s STEM learning ecosystem. Although the online content modules were a form of technology integration, we further developed and integrated other technologies for assessing students' STEM biases and identities. Most notably, we developed a digitized version of the Draw-a-Scientist-Task to evaluate students’ perceptions of scientists.

 

STEM for Everyone Culturally Responsive Career Modules

Title

NC Essential Standards and Other Pertinent Information

Introductory

Includes DAST pre-test and the S-STEM pre-test

Scientific Methods

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 3.P.2.2

Matter and Change

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 3.P.2, 4.P.2, and 5.P.2

Cornell Artificial Snow

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 3.E.2 and 5.E.1

Ecosystems

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 5.L.2.1

Air Quality

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 3.P.2.1

Learning to Pipette

Maps to NC Science Essential Standards 3.P.2.

Capstone Project

Includes DAST post-test and the S-STEM post-test

 

Implementation

In collaboration with Winston-Salem Forsyth County Schools Afterschool Program Director Kristine Brixius, the WSSU ITEST team delivered the eight STEM career modules as STEM enrichment for 91 underserved students participating in the 21st Century Community Learning Centers at Ashley, Easton, Kimberley Park, and Petree Elementary Schools during the summer of 2021. Our team targeted the four Title I schools because their science performance was below district and state averages. Evaluators from the University of Greensboro SERVE Center observed the implementation and provided the following findings from their observation:

Student Engagement

Regarding behavioral engagement (e.g., following directions, on-task behavior, taking notes), 83.33% of students were very descriptive of the observation, and 16.67% of students were descriptive of the observation. In terms of cognitive engagement (e.g., asking questions of teachers and each other, following up on each other’s responses, and actively listening), 33.33% of students were very descriptive of the observation, and 66.67% of students were descriptive of the observation. Finally, in terms of teachers helping enhance student engagement in the classroom, 83.33% were very descriptive of the observation whereas 16.67% were descriptive. Overall, 83.33% of students were highly engaged by using the eight STEM modules.

Technology Use Ratings

The evaluators used four basic constructs to assess students’ technology use (e.g., did the technology work smoothly, were issues resolved promptly, was technology effectively integrated into each session, and a composite summary score for students’ overall technology use) and rated observations on a Likert scale ranging from 0 (not observed) to 3 (very descriptive of the observation). Results indicated that the online STEM career modules were effectively integrated into each session. Still, technical difficulties not associated with the online modules precluded a smooth technical experience for students and slowed the resolution of technical problems.

Conclusions

This project provides a brave example of collaboration and integration. Beginning with the very composition of our grant team, we created interdisciplinary spaces that were culturally relevant and responsive to the needs STEM learners. As a result, the STEM career modules can be commercially duplicated and disseminated to school districts and homes across America and beyond. Our STEM for Everyone career modules and teacher professional development programs are full of valuable information that can powerfully impact teaching in North Carolina and beyond, engaging underserved students in ways that highlight and demystify STEM careers.       

 


Last Modified: 05/27/2022
Modified by: Breonte S Guy
